questions.text: Tinel’s sign is to elicit
questions.solution:
Tinel’s sign is to elicit nerve injury.

  • In closed injuries, percussion of the skin over a nerve in which axons have been ruptured evokes sensations usually described as a wave or surge of pins and needles into the cutaneous distribution of the nerve. This is Tinel’s sign and it is a most useful aid to diagnosis.
  • The sign is elicited on the day of injury in most conscious patients.
  • It indicates not only where the nerve has been injured but also the fact that at least some axons have been ruptured.
  • Tinel’s sign can be detected from such ‘motor’ nerves as the posterior interosseous nerve; sensory symptoms radiate into muscular territory rather than into skin.
  • It is more difficult to elicit the sign over deep-seated nerves such as the axillary, eighth cervical or first thoracic nerves.

Eliciting Tinel’s sign in closed lesions

  • The examiner’s finger percusses along the course of the nerve from distal to proximal, starting below the presumed level of lesion.
  • The patient is asked to say when the advancing finger elicits a wave or a surge of pins and needles or abnormal sensations, which may be painful, into the distribution of the nerve, which must be clearly indicated by the examiner.
  • The level of the sign should be measured from a fixed bony point and the distance recorded.
  • At times, the examination is painful.
  • A Tinel’s sign that remains static at the level of a lesion strongly suggests rupture of the nerve or persisting local conditions inimical to spontaneous regeneration.

questions.text: Positioning of the limbs along the cranio caudal axis in the flank regions of the embryo is regulated by
questions.solution:
Positioning of the limbs along the craniocaudal axis in the flank regions of the embryo is regulated by the HOX genes expressed along this axis.

  • These homeobox genes are expressed in overlapping patterns from head to tail with some having more cranial limits than others.
  • For example, the cranial limit of expression of H0XB8 is at the cranial border of the forelimb, and misexpression of this gene alters the position of these limbs.
  • Specification of the forelimb is regulated by the transcription factor TBX5.
  • Specification of the hind limb is regulated by TBX4.
  • SGR2 genes and FGF genes do not contribute to the positioning of the limbs.

6 Left side Left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus
Right side Right pulmonary artery

questions.text: Nerve supply of perineum is
questions.solution:
Nerve supply of perineum is by Pudendal Nerve

Nerve Origin Course Distribution
Pudendal nerve    Sacral plexus (anterior rami of S2–S4)  Exits pelvis via infra piriform part of greater sciatic foramen; passes posterior to sacrospinous ligament; enters perineumvia lesser sciatic foramen, immediately dividing into branches as it enters pudendalcanal  Motor to muscles of perineum and sensory to majority of perineal region via its branches, the inferior rectal and perineal nerves, and the dorsal nerve of clitoris or penis

questions.text: Renal cyst is a component of
questions.solution:
Renal cyst is a component of Meckel-Gruber syndrome and Bardet-BiedI syndrome.

Abscence in cilia related proteins causes

- Bardet-BiedI syndrome

characterized by : 

  • renal cysts
  • obesity
  • intellectual disability
  • limb defects

- Meckel-Gruber syndrome 

 characterized by :

  • renal cysts
  • hydrocephalus
  • microphthalmia
  • cleft palate
  • absence of the olfactory tract
  • polydactyly

- Because cilia are present on most cell types and in most tissues, many organ systems can be affected by abnormalities in ciliary structure and function.

- Denys-Drash syndrome consists of renal failure, ambiguous genitalia, and Wilms tumor.

The first part of the maxillary artery, the larger of the two end branches of the external carotid, run anteriorly, deep to the neck of the mandible and then pass deeply between the lateral and the medial pterygoid muscles.

questions.text: All of the following are false ribs except
questions.solution:
7th rib is a true rib.

True (vertebrosternal) ribs (1st–7th ribs):

  • They attach directly to the sternum through their own costal cartilages.

False (vertebrochondral) ribs (8th, 9th, and usually 10th ribs):

  • Their cartilages are connected to the cartilage of the rib above them; thus their connection with the sternum is indirect.

Floating (vertebral, free) ribs (11th, 12th, and sometimes 10th ribs):

  • The rudimentary cartilages of these ribs do not connect even indirectly with the sternum; instead they end in the posterior abdominal musculature.

Image showing false ribs:

questions.text: Regimental badge patch of skin is seen in injury to which of the following nerve
questions.solution:
Regimental badge patch of skin is seen in injury to axillary nerve.

  • An area of hypoaesthesia or anaesthesia over the distal part of the muscle (sometimes referred to as the ‘regimental badge patch’ of skin) reflecting loss of function in the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm (a branch of the axillary nerve), as well as venous occlusive changes (swelling) in the limb.

 

Regimental Badge sign

questions.text: A 47-year-old lady diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis presented to the clinic with the following deformity. The joint involved in this condition is an example of_________
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is hallux valgus. This is caused due to an excessive lateral deviation at the first metatarsophalangeal joint. It is an example of an ellipsoid joint. 

Ellipsoid joints have an oval, convex (male) surface fitting into an elliptical concave (female) surface. They show biaxial movements such as flexion-extension, and abduction–adduction. A combination of these movements results in circumduction. Movement on the third axis is prevented due to the general articular shape.

E.g., Wrist (radiocarpal) joint, atlanto-occipital joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, and metatarsophalangeal joints. 

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: The arterial supply of pericardium is mainly from

choices.text: Bronchial, esophageal, and superior phrenic arteries

questions.solution:
The arterial supply of pericardium is mainly from pericardiacophrenic artery.

The arterial supply of the pericardium

Mainly from a slender branch of the internal thoracic artery, the pericardiacophrenic artery, that often accompanies or at least parallels the phrenic nerve to the diaphragm.

Smaller contributions of blood come from the:

  • Musculophrenic artery-a terminal branch of the internal thoracic artery.
  • Bronchial, esophageal, and superior phrenic arteries-branches of the thoracic aorta.
  • Coronary arteries (visceral layer of serous pericardium only), the first branches of the aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of the chromatophilic material called Nissl substance in neural tissue?

choices.text: Site of mRNA translation for proteins of the axolemma
Becomes more abundant as an individual gets older

questions.solution:
• Nissl substance consists of granules that are distributedthroughout the cytoplasm of the cell body, except for theregion close to the axon,called the axon hillock .The granular material also extends into the proximal partsof the dendrites; it is not present in the axon.Electron micrographs show that the Nissl substanceis composed of rough-surfaced endoplasmic reticulum  arranged in the form of broad cisternae stackedone on top of the other.
  • Although many of the ribosomesare attached to the surface of the endoplasmic reticulum,many more lie free in the intervals between the cisternae.Since the ribosomes contain RNA, the Nissl substance isbasophilic and can be well demonstrated by staining withtoluidine blue or other basic aniline dyes and using the light microscope.
  • The Nissl substance is responsible for synthesizing protein,which flows along the dendrites and the axon and replaces the proteins that are broken down during cellular activity.
  • Fatigue or neuronal damage causes the Nissl substance tomove and become concentrated at the periphery of the cytoplasm.This phenomenon,which gives the impression that the Nissl substance has disappeared,is known as chromatolysis.

questions.text: All of the following are the extrinsic stabilizer of radioulnar joint except

choices.text: Dorsal and palmar radio ulnar ligament

questions.solution:
Dorsal and palmar radio ulnar ligament is the intrinsic stabilizer of radio ulnar joint.

Extrinsic stabilizers

 Extrinsic stabilizers include the

  • Tendon of extensorcarpi ulnaris
  • Pronator quadratus
  • The interosseous membrane
  • Sheath of the sixth dorsal compartment, which overlies extensor carpi ulnaris

Intrinsic stabilizers

Intrinsic stabilizers are stronger than extrinsic stabilizers.

They include the

  • radio-ulnar capsule and the dorsal and
  • Palmar radio-ulnar ligaments

Location of distal radio ulnar joint

Stabilizers of distal radio ulnar joint

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the gross appearance  of the cerebellum is true:

choices.text: It is separated from the occipital lobes of the cerebral hemispheres by the tentorium cerebelli
It lies anterior to the medulla oblongata and the pons
The anterior lobe is separated from the middle (posterior) lobe by the uvulonodular fissure
The flocculonodular lobe is separated from the middle (posterior) lobe by the horizontal fissure

questions.solution:
• The cerebellum is separated from the occipital lobes of the cerebral hemisphere by the tentorium cerebelli.
  • The cerebellum lies posterior to the medulla oblongata.
  • The anterior lobe is separated from the middle (posterior) lobe by the primary fissure.
  • The flocculonodular lobe is separated from the middle (posterior) lobe by the uvulonodular fissure.

The cerebellum is divided into three main lobes: theanterior lobe, the middle lobe, and the flocculonodularlobe. The anterior lobe may be seen on the superior surfaceof the cerebellum and is separated from the middlelobe by a wide V-shaped fissure called the primary fissure.

The middle lobe (sometimes called theposterior lobe),which is the largest part of the cerebellum,is situated between the primary and uvulonodular fissures.

The flocculonodular lobe is situated posterior to the uvulonodular fissure.

A deep horizontal fissurethat is found along the margin of the cerebellum separates the superior from the inferior surfaces; it is of no morphologicor functional significance.

Flattened view of the cerebellar cortex showing the main cerebellar lobes, lobules, and fissures.

questions.text: The arrow head points to
questions.solution:
In a blood smear platelets (arrows heads) are often found as aggregates.

  • Individually they show a lightly stained hyalomere region surrounding a more darkly stained central granulomere containing membrane-enclosed granules.
  • Ultrastructurally a platelet shows a system of microtubules and actin filaments near the periphery, called the marginal bundle, which is formed as the platelet pinches off from megakaryocyte, and helps maintain its shape.
  • Basophils, the rarest type of circulating leukocyte, have irregular bilobed nuclei and resemble mast cells with strongly basophilic specific granules.
  • Eosinophils have bilobed nuclei and eosinophilic specific granules.
  • Monocytes are larger agranulocytes with distinctly indented or C-shaped nuclei.
  • Neutrophils, the most abundant type of leukocyte, have polymorphic, multilobed nuclei, and faint pink cytoplasmic granules.
  • Lymphocytes range widely in size, depending on their activation state, and have roughly spherical nuclei with little cytoplasm and few organelles.

Peripheral Smears showing various blood cells showing their characteristic morphology

questions.text: True statement regarding Anterior papillary muscle is

choices.text: Most prominent of the three papillary muscles
Arises from the inferior wall of the right ventricle
Its tendinous cords attach to the septal and posterior cusps of the tricuspid valve

questions.solution:
Anterior papillary muscle is the most prominent of the three papillary muscles.

  • There are Three papillary muscles in the right ventricle correspond to the cusps of the tricuspid valve.
  • The anterior papillary muscle
    • The largest and most prominent of the three, arises from the anterior wall of the right ventricle; its tendinous cords attach to the anterior and posterior cusps of the tricuspid valve.
  • The posterior papillary muscle
    • smaller than the anterior muscle, may consist of several parts; it arises from the inferior wall of the right ventricle, and its tendinous cords attach to the posterior and septal cusps of the tricuspid valve.
  • The septal papillary muscle
    • Arises from the interventricular septum, and its tendinous cords attach to the anterior and septal cusps of the tricuspid valve.

questions.text: The structure labelled A in the image below is

choices.text: Main sensory nucleus of trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
Transverse Section Through the Cranial Part of pons 

The internal structure of the cranial part of the pons is similar to that seen at the caudal level , but it now contains the motor and principal sensory nuclei of the trigeminal nerve.

The motor nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is situated beneath the lateral part of the fourth ventricle within the reticular formation. The emerging motor fibers travel anteriorly through the substance of the pons and exit on its anterior surface.

The principal sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is situated on the lateral side of the motor nucleus, it is continuous inferiorly with the nucleus of the spinal tract.

The entering sensory fibers travel through the substance of the pons and lie lateral to the motor fibers.

Comparison of the different levels of the pons showing the major structures at each level

Level Cavity Nuclei Motor tracts Sensory tracts
Facial colliculus Fourth ventricle Facial nucleus, abducent nucleus, medial vestibular nucleus, spinal nucleus of cranial nerve V, pontine nuclei, trapezoid nuclei Corticospinal and corticonuclear tracts, transverse pontine fibers medial longitudinal fasciculus Spinal tract of cranial nerve V; lateral, spinal, and medial lemnisci
Trigeminal nuclei Fourth ventricle Main sensory and motor nucleus of cranial nerve V, pontine nuclei, trapezoid nuclei Corticospinal and corticonuclear tracts, transverse pontine fibers, medial longitudinal fasciculus   Lateral, spinal,and medial lemnisci

flexes metacarpophalangeal joints and extend interphalangeal joints
Dorsal Interossei Contiguous sides of shafts of metacarpal bones Proximal phalanges of index,middle, andring fingers anddorsal extens or expansion Deep branch ofulnar nerve C8; T1

Dorsal interossei abduct fingers from center of third finger

flexes metacarpophalangeal joints and extend interphalangeal joints

questions.text: Anatomically, the following structures collectively form the limbic system:

choices.text: The amygdaloid nucleus, the red nucleus, and the vestibular nuclei
The pulvinar of the thalamus and the substantia nigra
The cingulate gyrus and the uncus
The subcallosal, the cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyri, the hippocampal formation, the amygdaloid nucleus, the mammillary bodies, and the anterior thalamic nuclei

questions.solution:
• Medial aspect of the right cerebral hemisphere showing structures that form the limbic system.
  • The limbic system is made up of the subcallosal, the cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyri, the hippocampal formation, the amygdaloid nucleus, the mammillary bodies, and the anterior thalamic nuclei.

questions.text: Nerve supply of peroneus tertius is by
questions.solution:
Nerve supply of peroneus tertius is by Deep peroneal nerve.

  • Peroneus tertius is the muscle of anterior compartment of the leg.
  • The muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg such as
    • Tibialisanterior
    • Extensor digitorum longus
    • Peroneus tertius
    • Extensor halluces longus
    • Extensor digitorum brevis

are supplied by deep peroneal nerve.

  • Superficial peroneal nerve supplies the muscles in the lateral compartment of the leg.
  • Tibial nerve supplies the muscles in the posterior compartment of the leg.

questions.text: The following statements concern the gross appearance  of the cerebellum:

choices.text: It is separated from the occipital lobes of the cerebral hemispheres by the tentorium cerebelli
It lies anterior to the medulla oblongata and the pons
The anterior lobe is separated from the middle (posterior) lobe by the uvulonodular fissure
The flocculonodular lobe is separated from the middle (posterior) lobe by the horizontal fissure

questions.solution:
• The cerebellum is separated from the occipital lobes of the cerebral hemisphere by the tentorium cerebelli.
  • The cerebellum lies posterior to the medulla oblongata.
  • The anterior lobe is separated from the middle (posterior) lobe by the primary fissure.
  • The flocculonodular lobe is separated from the middle (posterior) lobe by the uvulonodular fissure.

The cerebellum is divided into three main lobes: the anterior lobe, the middle lobe, and the flocculonodularlobe. The anterior lobe may be seen on the superior surfaceof the cerebellum and is separated from the middlelobe by a wide V-shaped fissure called the primary fissure.

The middle lobe (sometimes called theposterior lobe),which is the largest part of the cerebellum,is situated between the primary and uvulonodular fissures.

The flocculonodular lobe is situated posterior to the uvulonodular fissure.

A deep horizontal fissurethat is found along the margin of the cerebellum separates the superior from the inferior surfaces; it is of no morphologicor functional significance.

questions.solution:
The muscle which compresses and supports the abdominal viscera is

  • External oblique
  • Internal oblique
  • Transversus abdominis
  • Rectus abdominis

Muscles of antero lateral abdominal wall

Muscle Origin  Insertion
External oblique External surfaces of 5th–12th ribs Linea alba, pubic tubercle, and anterior half of iliac crest 
Internal oblique Thoracolumbar fascia,anterior two thirds of iliac crest, and connective tissue deep to lateral third of inguinal ligament  Inferior borders of 10th–12th ribs, linea alba, and pecten pubis via conjointtendon
Transversus abdominis Internal surfaces of 7th–12th costal cartilages, thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, and connective tissue deep to lateral third of inguinal ligament  Linea alba with aponeurosis of internal oblique, pubic crest, and pectin pubis via conjoint tendon
Rectus abdominis Pubic symphysis andpubic crest  Xiphoid process and 5th–7th costal cartilages

Anteriolateral abdominal wall-showing superficial dissection, the anterior layer of rectus sheath is reflected on the side.

questions.text: The following gives the sensory nerve supply to the sole of the foot except

choices.text: Medial calcaneal branch of the tibial nerve
Lateral calcaneal branch of the tibial nerve

questions.solution:
Sensory nerve supply to the sole of the foot is by

  • Medial calcaneal branch of the tibial nerve
  • Medial plantar nerve
  • Lateral plantar nerve

Medial calcaneal branch of the tibial nerve - innervates the medial side of the heel.

Medial plantar nerve - innervate the medial two thirds of the sole.

Lateral plantar nerve - innervate the lateral third of the sole.

questions.text: Inguinal falx refers to
questions.solution:
Inguinal falx refers to conjoint tendon.

Boundaries of inguinal canal

Boundary Lateral Third/Deep Ring Middle Third Medial Third/Superficial Ring  
Posterior wall Transversalis fascia Transversalis fascia Inguinal falx (conjoint tendon) plus refl ectedinguinal ligament 
Anterior wall Internal oblique plus lateral crus of  aponeurosis of external oblique Aponeurosis of external oblique (lateral crus and intercrural fibers) Aponeurosis of external oblique (intercrural fibers), with fascia of external oblique continuingonto cord as external spermatic fascia 
Roof Transversalis fascia Musculo-aponeurotic arches of internaloblique and transverse abdominal  Medial crus of aponeurosis of external oblique
Floor Iliopubic tract Inguinal ligament Lacunar ligament

questions.text: All of the following are the anterior bursa of knee joint except
questions.solution:
Semimembranous bursa -posterior bursa of knee joint:

Anterior Bursae

  • Suprapatellar bursa lies beneath the quadriceps muscle and communicates with the joint cavity.
  • Prepatellar bursa lies in the subcutaneous tissue between the skin and the front of the lower half of the patella and the upper part of the ligamentum patellae.
  • Superficial infrapatellar bursa lies in the subcutaneous tissue between the skin and the front of the lower part of the ligamentum patellae.
  • Deep infrapatellar bursa lies between the ligamentum patellae and the tibia.

Posterior Bursae

  • Popliteal bursa is found in association with the tendon of the popliteus and communicates with the joint cavity.
  • Semimembranosus bursa is found related to the insertion of the semimembranosus muscle and may communicate with the joint cavity.

questions.text: The midbrain has

choices.text: A cavity called the cerebral aqueduct
A cavity that opens above into the lateral ventricle
A location in the middle cranial fossa of the skull

questions.solution:
The midbrain develops from the midbrain vesicle,the cavity of which becomes much reduced to form the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius.

The midbrain

  • Has a cavity called the cerebral aqueduct
  • Is of small size
  • Is completely surrounded with cerebrospinal fluid in the subarachnoid space
  • Has a cavity called the cerebral aqueduct, which opens above into the third ventricle
  • Is located in the posterior cranial fossa

questions.text: The arterial supply of scrotum is from

choices.text: Posterior scrotal branches of the perineal artery
Anterior scrotal branches of the deep external pudendal artery

questions.solution:
The arterial supply of scrotum is from

  • Posterior scrotal branches of the perineal artery
  • Anterior scrotal branches of the deep external pudendal artery
  • Cremasteric artery
    • Posterior scrotal branches of the perineal artery: a branch of the internal pudendal artery.
    • Anterior scrotal branches of the deep external pudendal artery: a branch of the femoral artery.
    • Cremasteric artery: a branch of the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Scrotal veins accompany the arteries.
  • The lymphatic vessels of the scrotum drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

questions.text: True statement regarding Talipes calcaneovalgus is

choices.text: Foot is dorsiflexed at the ankle joint
Foot is everted at the midtarsal joints
Foot is plantar flexed at the ankle joint

questions.solution:
Talipes calcaneovalgus is a form of club foot in which the foot is dorsiflexed at the ankle joint and everted at the midtarsal joints.

  • In talipes equinovarus, the foot is plantar flexed at the ankle joint and inverted at the midtarsal joints.
  • Metatarsus varus (metatarsus adductus) is a common condition in which the forefoot is adducted on the rear part of the foot. Correction may be accomplished by manipulation followed by splinting.
  • Overriding toes most commonly involve the fourth and fifth toes. The fourth toe is depressed and overridden by the fifth toe. This may be corrected by the application of splints.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the relationship of spleen except
questions.solution:
Left kidney forms medial boundary of spleen.

The relations of the spleen are:

  • Anteriorly-the stomach
  • Posteriorly-the left part of the diaphragm, which separates it from the pleura, lung, and ribs 9–11
  • Inferiorly-the left colic flexure
  • Medially-the left kidney

Anterior view of spleen and its relations

Hilum of spleen and anatomy of spleen

questions.text: Pes planus is due to

choices.text: Plantarflexion of the first ray and forefoot valgus

questions.solution:
Pes planus is due to Depressed medial longitudinal arch.

Pes planus (flat foot)

  • Medial longitudinal arch is depressed or collapsed.
  • As a result, the forefoot is displaced laterally and everted.
  • The head of the talus is no longer supported, and the body weight forces it downward and medially between the calcaneum and the navicular bone.
  • When the deformity has existed for some time, the plantar, calcaneonavicular, and medial ligaments of the ankle joint become permanently stretched, and the bones change shape.
  • The muscles and tendons are also permanently stretched.
  • The causes of flat foot are both congenital and acquired.
  • Most cases are caused by muscle imbalance, in many instances resulting from poliomyelitis.

questions.text: After a hemorrhage into the left internal capsule in a right-handed person, the following sign or symptom might be present:

choices.text: Normal speech & Left-sided positive Babinski response

questions.solution:
There is a right homonymous hemianopia.

Right hemiplegia is present.

There is aphasia.

There is a right-sided positive Babinski response.

Although both hemispheres are almost identical in structure, in the majority of the adult population, handedness, perception of language, speech, spatial judgment, and areas of behavior are controlled by one hemisphere and not the other.

About 90% of people are right-handed, and the control resides in the left hemisphere.

The remainder are left-handed, and a few individuals are ambidextrous.

In 96% of individuals, speech and understanding of spoken and written language are controlled by the left hemisphere. Thus, in most adults, the left cerebral hemisphere is dominant.

From a clinical point of view,the age at which cerebral dominance comes into effect is important.

questions.text: The length of the prostatic urethra is
questions.solution:
The length of the prostatic urethra is 3-4 cm.

Parts of male urethra and its length

Part  Length
Intramural (pre prostatic) part  0.5–1.5 cm
Prostatic urethra   3.0–4.0 cm
Intermediate(membranous)Part  1.0–1.5 cm
Spongy urethra  ~15 cm

Female urethra is approximately 4 cm long.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man presented with ipsilateral paralysis. Examination showed hypertonia, hyperreflexia and the following finding. Which region of white matter do not contain the damaged fibres?

choices.text: Lateral white column of the spinal cord
Anterior limb of the internal capsule

questions.solution:
The given scenario of ipsilateral paralysis, hypertonia, hyperreflexia and ankle clonus (image) is suggestive of a corticospinal tract lesion. The anterior limb of the internal capsule does not contain corticospinal fibres. It passes through the posterior limb of internal capsule.

Corticospinal fibres have the following course as shown in the image below:

questions.text: Resistance to pressure is the main function of
questions.solution:
Resistance to pressure is the main function of type 2 collagen.

 

Some important collagen types with their function are

Type Major Location Main Function
I Skin, tendon, bone, dentin Resistance to tension
II Cartilage, vitreous body Resistance to pressure
III Skin, muscle, bloodvessels, frequently together with type I Structural maintenancein expansible organs

V Fetal tissues, skin,bone, placenta, mostinterstitial tissues Participates in type Icollagen function

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with pain, numbness, and fatigue of the right arm. Angiography reveals decreased flow through the vessels anastomosing near the surgical neck of the humerus. The pathology is likely to be present in which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The branches of the third part of the axillary artery supply the surgical neck of the humerus. Thrombus in this part will cause decreased supply in its branches - the anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries.

Branches of 3rd part of the axillary artery are:

  • Anterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Posterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Subscapular artery (not involved in the anastomosis)

Fracture of the surgical neck is the commonest site among all proximal humerus fractures due to its inherent weakness. Fracture at this site may cause injury to the posterior circumflex humeral artery and the axillary nerve that accompanies it.

Positional compression of the axillary artery is seen in athletes who are involved with throwing movement, as in baseball players. Repeated movement of the humerus may cause compression of the distal part of the axillary artery. This may lead to thrombosis or aneurysm resulting in arm ischemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with pain and stiffness of the right hip.  Ultrasonography revealed effusion in the right hip joint. At which position of hip joint will the pain be minimal?
questions.solution:
A patient with an effusion in the hip joint is has least pain in flexed and abducted position.

Joint capacity is maximal when the hip joint is held in a partially flexed and abducted position. Hence, a patient with an effusion in the hip joint is therefore most comfortable in this position.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after being injured in mob violence. The patient had a penetrating injury in the right shoulder region by a sharp glass piece. On examination, there was drooping of the right shoulder associated with winging of the scapula. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Injury to the spinal accessory nerve can cause both drooping of the shoulder and winging of the scapula.

The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes: 

  • Retraction of scapula
  • Shrugging of the shoulder
  • Overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior)

Nerves causing winging of the scapula:

Nerves Muscles Type of winging
Spinal accessory nerve

Trapezius and sternocleidomastoid

 The superior angle of the scapula becomes more prominent (lateral winging)
Long thoracic nerve

Serratus anterior

 The scapula is pulled upwards and towards the spine by the unopposed action of the trapezius (medial winging)
Dorsal scapular nerve Levator scapulae, rhomboid major, and rhomboid minor Similar to serratus anterior but mild winging

questions.text: You are testing the deep tendon reflexes in a patient with Guillan-Barre syndrome. Which spinal segment is tested predominantly by a tap on the triceps tendon?
questions.solution:
A tap on the tendon of the triceps posterior to the elbow mainly tests for C7.

A tap on the tendon of the biceps in the cubital fossa tests mainly for spinal cord level C6.

Abdominal

Lower Quadrants- Intercostal, iliohypogastric & ilioinguinal

Upper Quadrants-T7- T10 

Lower Quadrants-T10- Upper Lumbar segments

Anal   S2, S3, S4

questions.text:
Chopart's ligament is related to which of the following joints?
  1. Calcaneocuboid joint
  2. Naviculocuneiform joint
  3. Calcaneonavicular joint
  4. Talonavicular joint
  5. Metatarsocuneiform joint
questions.solution:
Chopart's ligament is related to both calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular joints.

Chopart's ligament/ Bifurcate ligament is a strong Y- shaped band, having a proximal stem and 2 distal limbs.

  • The proximal limb is attached by a stem to the anterior part of upper calcaneal surface.
  • The distal limb divides into calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular parts.

The image given below shows the Chopart's ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form deep relations of the hyoglossus muscle?
questions.solution:
The lingual nerve lies in superficial relation to the hyoglossus muscle.

Superficial or lateral relations of the hyoglossus include:

  • Digastric tendon
  • Styloglossus, and mylohyoid
  • Lingual nerve and submandibular ganglion
  • Sublingual gland, the deep part of the submandibular gland and duct
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • The deep lingual vein

Deep or medial relations of hyoglossus are:

  • Glossopharyngeal nerve
  • Lingual artery.
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Genioglossus
  • Middle constrictor
  • Inferior longitudinal muscles of the tongue

questions.text: The length of the intra-orbital part of optic nerve is
questions.solution:
The intraorbitalpart of Optic nerve measures 25-30mm.

The optic nerve measures around 45-50mm

  • Intra ocular part 1mm
  • Intraorbital part 25-30 mm
  • Intra canalicular part 5-9mm
  • Intracranial part 10-16mm

Optic nerve lacks neurilemmal sheath, hence doesn’t regenerate
It lies superomedial to the ophthalmic artery in the optic canal which crosses obliquely over it.
Its fibres are myelinated by oligo dendrocytes.

questions.text: The structure marked with arrow in the image given below is concerned with _______.

choices.text: Secretion of the CSF into the subarachnoid space
Transport of neurochemicals from subjacent neurons and glia into CSF
Absorption of the CSF by the arachnoid villi
CSF return through the tela choroidea

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is a dural venous sinus, and the CSF is absorbed into this sinus through arachnoid villi. 

Tela choroidea gives rise to the choroid plexus, from which CSF is secreted into the ventricles.

Tancytes/specialized glial cells in circumventricular organs help with the transport of neurochemicals to CSF.

questions.text: A woman presented with hemiparesis due to a spinal cord tumour. The doctor diagnosed this as a case of Brown- Séquard syndrome. All are true about this syndrome except:

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of crude touch sensations
Ipsilateral paralysis below the level of lesion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Brown- Séquard syndrome. Ipsilateral loss of crude touch sensation is not seen in this syndrome.

Brown- Séquard syndrome is the hemisection of the spinal cord. This causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways. 

  • The damage to the dorsal column pathway leads to ipsilateral loss of fine touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.
  • The damage to the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.
  • The damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces ipsilateral paralysis of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)
